title: Expert Opinions & Advice
content:
**Column 1: Dr. Randeep Guleria**
HMPV is not a new virus.
Usually causes mild illness.
Can cause pneumonia in infants, elderly, and those with comorbidities.
Symptomatic treatment is usually sufficient (rest, hydration, fever medication).
Avoid crowded places.
**Column 2: Union Health Minister JP Nadda & Others**
No need for widespread panic.
Situation is being closely monitored.
Government is taking proactive measures.
Public urged to remain calm and follow guidelines.
image_desc:
A split image showing photos of Dr. Randeep Guleria and Union Health Minister JP Nadda. Type: photo collage

### Video Suggestion:
N/A
narration: Leading health experts, including Dr. Randeep Guleria, former AIIMS director, have reassured the public that HMPV is not a novel virus and typically causes mild illness.  However, he stressed the importance of vigilance, especially for infants, the elderly, and those with underlying health conditions.  The Union Health Minister, JP Nadda, and other officials have echoed this sentiment, urging calm and emphasizing the government's monitoring of the situation.  Dr. Guleria advises symptomatic treatment – rest, hydration, and managing fever – and recommends avoiding crowded areas to prevent the spread of infection.

title: Prevention & Mitigation
content: (Caption below image)  While there's no specific vaccine for HMPV,  regular flu shots and COVID-19 vaccination can offer some level of protection.

narration: Although there isn't a specific vaccine for HMPV, health experts suggest that regular flu vaccinations and the COVID-19 vaccine may offer some level of cross-protection.  Maintaining good hygiene practices, such as regular handwashing, also remains crucial.

title: Stay Informed & Updated
content:
Monitor official health advisories.
Practice good hygiene.
Consult a doctor if you experience symptoms.
